texts.definition: The enjoyment to be had when failing in a spectacular way in a game.
markups: <style="Definition">The enjoyment to be had when failing in a spectacular way in a game.</style>

Things do not always do the way players wants in games. However, sometimes things go horribly bad that it becomes a perverse form of entertainment, especially if players cannot do anything to correct or avoid problems. Such <style="CurrentLink">Spectacular Failure Enjoyment</style> can be as interesting as winning the games, are typically more interesting to retell to others since they are more unique.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/RoboRally">RoboRally</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Alert">Space Alert</link></style> are two <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style> where players need to commit to several actions that will then be executed in sequence. Since mistakes can have been made, especially concerning what other players are doing at the same time, it is quite likely that players will realize they have a faulty plan but cannot do anything to correct this. Since even the smallest mistakes can cause large problems, this is likely to force players to have <style="CurrentLink">Spectacular Failure Enjoyment</style>.

Some <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> like <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Paranoia">Paranoia</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fiasco">Fiasco</link></style> embrace <style="CurrentLink">Spectacular Failure Enjoyment</style>, most often in a dark humorous way. This is sometimes done in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Live%20Action%20Roleplaying%20Games">Live Action Roleplaying Games</link></style>, most often in the Nordic LARP style where players may be "playing to lose" to create good stories. Examples of LARPs where this has happened include the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Monitor%20Celestra">Monitor Celestra</link></style>.

Both the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/X-COM%20series">X-COM</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> often require that all characters work in conjunction, and failing to do this can so quickly cause total failures that this can become <style="CurrentLink">Spectacular Failure Enjoyment</style>.

Players that have contributed to the wiki of Slaves to Armok II: Dwarf Fortress consider fun equal to losing, having a redirect link from Fun" to "Losing and on the "Losing" page discuss the reasoning behind this. For those that fail to lose, and thereby have fun, they offer suggestion on how to sabotage your own chances by taking on additional challenges.
This pattern reflects that a failure which distinguishes itself in some way, e.g. as the result of exceptional bad luck, gross ineptness, or overwhelming opposition, can be enjoyable.

The basis for <style="CurrentLink">Spectacular Failure Enjoyment</style> can be created by not only having <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> regarding possible failure during gameplay, but also from the failure unfolding slow enough so <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> still can be continued to be felt while it is happening. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Perceivable%20Consequences">Perceivable Consequences</link></style> is one general requirement for this, but <style="Link"><link="action-programming">Action Programming</link></style> (as used in for example <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/RoboRally">RoboRally</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Alert">Space Alert</link></style>) can specifically create the requirements for this type of <style="CurrentLink">Spectacular Failure Enjoyment</style>. <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="team-elimination">Team Elimination</link></style> can also cause <style="CurrentLink">Spectacular Failure Enjoyment</style> but this is very context dependent and ends the gameplay for those involved.

<style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> is one way to increase the chances of <style="CurrentLink">Spectacular Failure Enjoyment</style> but this requires that players are willing to accept the challenge level provided. It does so be letting players have the risk of either misjudging their opposition or by making small mistakes be able to escalate into complete failures; games that can provide <style="Link"><link="fubar-enjoyment">FUBAR Enjoyment</link></style> have these prerequisites, so aiming at supporting this pattern is one way of creating the basis for <style="CurrentLink">Spectacular Failure Enjoyment</style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Coordination">Coordination</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Simultaneous%20Challenges">Simultaneous Challenges</link></style>, and requiring <style="Link"><link="team-combos">Team Combos</link></style> can have similar effects without players necessarily feeling that they are challenging. <style="Link"><link="ever-increasing-difficulty">Ever Increasing Difficulty</link></style> relies on other patterns to provide the actual challenge but scales up the difficulty until it is at a level which is beyond players' skills and thereby can cause <style="CurrentLink">Spectacular Failure Enjoyment</style>.

Even if a failure can lead to <style="CurrentLink">Spectacular Failure Enjoyment</style> in a game, this does not mean that the same failure is enjoyable many times. For this reason, <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> can help other patterns create different and unique-feeling <style="CurrentLink">Spectacular Failure Enjoyment</style> moments. <style="Link"><link="critical-misses">Critical Misses</link></style> is a particular pattern typically associated with <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> that can ruin otherwise well-working game plans. <style="Link"><link="friendly-fire">Friendly Fire</link></style> can do the same but has a higher risk of not being enjoyable and may cause players to become <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Scapegoats">Scapegoats</link></style>.

Players may themselves strive for <style="CurrentLink">Spectacular Failure Enjoyment</style> by doing high-risk activities or planning for failure. This can be encouraged in designs by supporting the <style="Link"><link="playing-lose">Playing to Lose</link></style> pattern. <style="Link"><link="ragequitting">Ragequitting</link></style> and <style="CurrentLink">Spectacular Failure Enjoyment</style> are mutually exclusive to each other, so designing for one is designing against the other.

<style="CurrentLink">Spectacular Failure Enjoyment</style> typically create a comical or remarkable sequences of <style="Link"><link="exceptional-events">Exceptional Events</link></style>. This makes it more likely that the players experiencing them are going to engage in telling <style="Link"><link="game-instance-stories">Game Instance Stories</link></style> to let others know about them than for other gameplay sequences. The rememberability of <style="CurrentLink">Spectacular Failure Enjoyment</style> make it likely to help create <style="Link"><link="togetherness">Togetherness</link></style> between players that experience the spectacular failure together.
